page.title: 09History of Pensilva.
page.content: In the Iron Age there were many settlements in the Caradon Hill area. The remains of{hut circles}can be seen on the moors. At Tokenbury the Roundabury shows the place of an Iron Age camp. A change in climate and loss of soil fertility made people move to lower ground, leaving only a few metal workers behind. By Norman times{manor {houses}had been built at Penharget, Bicton and Trebeigh, and later still Slade and Tokenbury. The village of{Pensilva}did not appear until the middle of the 19th century. {Copper}was discovered in the area and many mines started. In a few years as many as 2,000 people were living here and the same number in nearby Caradon Town. At first the area was known as Bodminland but later became{Pensilva {(Pen - headland, high ground and {silva - trees.)
